_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

The facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Anhydrous Ammonia Storage System and the Aqueous Ammonia Storage System.  The facility's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The primary activity at the facility is the storage, and sale of fertilizers, in addition to, the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to farmers, including regulated substances:  Anhydrous and aqueous ammonia.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.  Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored at the site in an 18,000 gallon bullet tank.  The facility implements administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia to 82% of the bullet tank capacity. The total capacity stored onsite is 56,000 pounds; which is based on the number of gallons stored onsite (12,000 gallons) and the specific gravity of ammonia (0.682).



Aqueous ammonia (24% of ammonia by weight) is stored in two 24,500-gallon above ground tanks at the site.  The total quantity of ammonia present in the aqueous ammonia, based on 24% ammonia by weight and the specific gravity of ammonia, is approximately 67,000 pounds. 



The anhydrous and aqueous ammonia at the facility is considered retail, since anhydrous ammonia from the facility is delivered directly to the farmer (end user), thus is required to follow the EPA RMP Program 2. However, the facility currently follows the CalARP Program 3 requirements for anhydrous ammonia and Program 2 for aqueous ammonia as required by the San Joaquin County Office of Emergency Services, the CalARP Participating Agency (PA) for the local

Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA).





HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

The Facility's 04/21/2009 Hazard Assessment is in the process of being reviewed and updated.  Section 8.a. of this RMP will be corrected when the Hazard Assessment review and updates are completed (targeted completion by 6/30/2014). 



The Offsite Consequence Analysis part of the Hazard Assessment was reviewed and revised June 2014 and is summarized as follows:



Worst-Case Release Scenario

Based on the EPA RMP guidance, the worst-case release scenarios is defined as a release from the largest storage vessel at the facility. The anhydrous ammonia worst-case scenario is a release of 56,000 pounds from the anhydrous ammonia bullet tank.  The aqueous ammonia worst-case scenario is a release of approximately 33,500 pounds of ammonia from one of the aqueous ammonia storage tanks.

  

Alternative Release Scenario

Based on the EPA RMP guidance, the alternative-case release scenarios is defined as a release scenario that is more likely than the worst-case release scenario. The anhydrous ammonia alternative case scenario is a release during the transfer of ammonia from the bullet tank to a nurse tank. The aqueous ammonia the alternative-case scenario is a release from a 4-inch hose during the transfer between a storage tank and the delivery truck.

 

Risk Considerations

Ammonia is a toxic inhalational hazard; and thus, the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks to potentially reach sensitive populations within the community. The facility's identified potential risks for an ammonia release from its process are included in the off-site consequence analysis, Hazard Assessment, and Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  Facility RMP elements and other safety programs are structured to minimize the potential of a release from the identified risks. 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The facility employs a safety specialist to coordinate training

and implementation of the RMP.



As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 2 (aqueous ammonia) and Program 3 (anhydrous ammonia), key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of anhydrous and aqueous ammonia.  Prevention elements for each program are listed below.

- Process Safety Information (PSI) 

- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

- Operating Procedures (OP)

- Training (TRN)

- Mechanical Integrity (MI)

- Management of Change (MOC) (anhydrous only)

- Pre-Startup Review (PSSR) (anhydrous only)

- Compliance Audits (CA)

- Incident Investigation (II)

- Employee Participation (EP) (anhydrous only)

- Hot Work Permit (HWP) (anhydrous only)

- Contractors (CON) (anhydrous only)

- Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)



In addition, the facility is completely fenced and the gate is closed and locked when the facility is closed.  A security guard completes visual inspections of the ammonia systems three times per night.  



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no CalARP-applicable releases of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.  



EXTERNAL EVENTS ANALYSIS

Pursuant to the requirements of California Health & Safety Code, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7 (q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of anhydrous or aqueous ammonia were addressed by the PHA.



FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE

The use of flammable materials at the Wilbur-Ellis Manteca Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 



FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE

The use of flammable materials at the Wilbur-Ellis Manteca Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 

The Wilbur-Ellis Manteca Facility is not a First Responding fac

ility and therefore employees are trained to evacuate and call 911 in case of an emergency.  Wilbur-Ellis Manteca Facility has filed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) that follows the requirements of the CCR Title 8 ?3220, with the local fire department and the local CalARP authority.  The responding fire department is located approximately 2.8 miles from the facility and inspects the facility on a regular basis; and has participated in facility emergency response drills.

 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Wilbur-Ellis is committed to continuously making safety improvements. To improve the safety of the anhydrous ammonia system, Wilbur-Ellis is in the process of developing a more comprehensive anhydrous ammonia inspection checklist for the bullet tank system and nurse tanks.  The comprehensive checklist will include daily, weekly, and annual inspection frequencies, including visual and non-destructive tests to evaluate the mechanical integrity of the tanks, valves, piping, etc. At a minimum, inspection frequencies will follow industry standards.  



Wilbur-Ellis is also implementing a facility-wide comprehensive corrective action/preventative action (CAPA) log to track and facilitate completion of listed CAs on a timely basis.  Recommended improvements and identified deficiencies from the inspection checklists, compliance audits, and PHA studies will be included on the facility CAPA log along with the priority, employee responsible, and targeted completion dates.
